snippet: Although a spotlight fell on Ann Romney, 65 percent of married women raising children full time live in households with annual incomes below $75,000.
abstract: Majority of stay-at-home mothers live in households that earn less than $75,000 a year; decision to remain at home is often related to an inability to find a good job, lack of education and the high cost of child care.

byline.contributor: Theo Emery contributed reporting from Washington, Dan Frosch from Denver, and Ian Lovett from Los Angeles.

lead_paragraph: Although a spotlight fell on Ann Romney, 65 percent of married women raising children full time live in households with annual incomes below $75,000.

headline.seo: Ann Romney’s Choice Not Typical of Stay-at-Home Mothers
headline.main: For Most, Choice of Stay-at-Home Motherhood Is Far From a Luxury
headline.print_headline: For Most, Choice of Stay-at-Home Motherhood Is Far From a Luxury
